conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to consider the forces acting on the system.
Three light ropes of length L are connected to two points C and D respectively, with both ends A and B suspended on the horizontal ceiling, 2L apart. A weight of mass m is suspended on point C.
The weight of the mass m is suspended at point C.
The CD rope is connected to point C and suspended from point D.
The AB rope is connected to point A and suspended from point B.
Point D is suspended from the AB rope.
The weight of the mass m is suspended from point C.
The CD rope is connected to point C and suspended from point D.
For every force applied to point D, there is an equal and opposite force acting on point D.
The force applied on point D must be equal in magnitude but opposite in direction to the force exerted by the weight of the mass m.
The weight of the mass m is suspended from point C.
The CD rope is connected to point C and suspended from point D.
The AB rope is connected to point A and suspended from point B.
Point C is suspended from the CD rope.
The weight of the mass m is suspended from point C.
The AB rope is connected to point A and suspended from point B.
For every force applied to point C, there is an equal and opposite force acting on point C.
The force applied on point C must be equal in magnitude but opposite in direction to the force exerted by the weight of the mass m.
The minimum force required to keep the CD rope level is the force exerted by the weight of the mass m.
The weight of the mass m is \( m \times g \), where \( g \) is the acceleration due to gravity (approximately 9.8 m/sÂ²).
The minimum value of force that can be applied on point D is \( m \times g \).
